text:
This is a very good recipe which I will definitely use again.  After reading other reviews, I made a couple adjustments.  I salted the grated zucchini first and let it sit in a colander to draw out the excess moisture.  Then I patted it dry with paper towels.  I also added some fresh chopped garlic and Italian-style bread crumbs to the mixture.  Then, after forming the patties, I patted on more bread crumbs.  They fried up nice and crispy.  I served them with marinara sauce, which my husband and I both thought was the perfect accompaniment.

WOW! These are soooo good! Very easy to make. I tweaked the recipe a bit though since it seemed a little bland as is. I added some black pepper, parsley and garlic. I also threw in some chopped mushrooms since they go so well with zucchini. I think next time I'll try different cheeses and other complementary veggies like red bell pepper. These would probably go really well with some marinara sauce too.

None
text:
These zucchini patties are AWESOME!! My husband and I both loved them--I can't wait to make them for others. I did tweak the recipe a bit and followed the suggestions of others. The liquid from the zucchini absolutely needs to be squeezed out to make this work--otherwise it will be much too runny. Here is what I did: used 3 eggs instead of 2 (i had a bit more onion and zucchini than what was called for), added 3 cloves of pressed garlic, a 1/2 tsp. of red pepper flakes, 3/4 to a full cup of italian seasoned bread crumbs, and 1/2 c. of cheddar (on top of the other cheeses). Also, I lessened the amount of flour to maybe 1/4 c. Lastly, I sprinkled the patties with bread crumbs before frying. Will definitely make this again--can't wait in fact!

These are great with the recipe as is, but they turn out a little better if you drain the excess water off of the Zuc first. I've also used just a Tablespoon of flour and a 1/3 cup of seasoned bread crumbs to replace the 1/2 cup flour, to add more flavor and they were fabulous.

city:

country:
None
text:
I make these patties all the time. For a more healthy way I bake them in a jelly roll pan at 375 for 20 min then turn them and bake for an additional 15. Time depends on your oven, the size of the patties and thickness. I spray the bottom of the pan with PAM. I squeeze as much water out of the zucchini as possible and I don't use salt. The salt makes the zucchini more runny. There is enough salt in the cheeses and you can always salt them after they are baked. I also use 1/2 cup of pepper jack cheese and 1/2 cup of feta instead of the mozzarella cheese. These cheeses give the patties a better taste. I don't use any oil or flour in my patties. I use Italian bread crumbs I also double the recipe but don't double the eggs.

Hey, this is Sherlie!  Thank you so much for all your kind reviews and thanks for trying my recipe. I am so thrilled that it is so popular and that Allrecipes has put it in several of their cookbooks.  It is a versatile recipe and can be varied with any indgredients except of course the zucchini.  One of the best tips for making it is to drain the zucchini as it makes the batter runny if you dont and doing that in a couple of paper towels works wonderfully.  Just wring it out.  Thanks again, readers.  You are a great bunch!!!

text:
Wow, a versatile recipe for vegetarians and meat-lovers alike. I love them crispy and hot right out of the pan, and my husband prefers the flabby, soft, reheated leftovers. Here's a few tips:

1. Make sure you squeeze the excess liquid out of the grated zucchini. Salting it helps, then let it sit in a strainer for a while, then squeeze out the rest with paper towels.

2. I think they taste much better when you don't use plain flour. Bisquick, mashed potato flakes, and even whole wheat flour give a much better flavor.

3. Try adding a bit of cayenne pepper or red pepper flakes... yum!

4. These are great for using up that last bit of whatever vegetable you have on hand. I've added some grated carrot, yellow squash, or chopped red pepper. There's a million ways to change it up; try one of your own, then share the results with the rest of us!

I also grilled mine on a George Forman Grill, so I didn't have to fry them.  I was very pleased with the outcome.  So if you want to cut some of the fat and calories, grilling these is an option.  Thank you for the great recipe!

text:
4 stars as written, but it's a definite 5 star with a few changes. It's really important to squeeze as much excess liquid out of the shredded zucchini before mixing it with the rest of the ingredients - otherwise, these would be too mushy/wet. I used about a 1/2 cup of bread crumbs and 1/8 cup of flour. I also added 2 cloves of garlic and a small bunch of fresh basil to the mix. They are soooo freakin' good. Just like crab cakes, but without the expensive crab. We'll be making these a lot.

Fantastic! To puff up the zucchini a bit, I added some baking powder, just like in potato pancakes. I made these for my DH who is low-carbing it instead of making potato pancakes. You couldn't even tell the difference. They are fantastic - serve them with sour cream (my fav) or applesauce (an old German tradition with potato pancakes.) I shallow-fried these first then finished off in a 425 oven for about 10 minutes. Yummy!!!

As I'm sure others either know or have learned, draining the zucchini really does ensure the success of this recipe.  To give it a little kick beyond the fairly quiet taste of the mozzarella, I used Pepper Jack cheese and we both loved the little surprise of "bite." I loved these and even tho' I pretty much forced them on tonight's menu despite knowing Hub is not fond of them,  I was quite pleased when he reported he liked them.  I served these with the suggested little plop of sour cream and  some fresh chives, but I think the tomato sauce idea sounds good and tempting too!

text:
These were REALLY good! I guess I used the recipe as a "base" because I added 5 chopped baby port mushrooms, 1 chopped sweet red pepper, potato flakes, garlic, black pepper and paprika. I didn't drain the zucchini, or add salt until it was in the pan, I also omitted the flour. I switched out the mozz. for sharp white cheddar and added an egg. I let it sit for a minute or two while the pan heated up to allow the potato flakes to absorb some of the zucchini juice. These were so good. I served them with smashed (lightly seasoned) avocado.

text:
These are delicious. A great recipe that we will use often due to great zucchini success in the garden this year. After shredding, I put the zucchini in a colander and sprinkled a couple of teasp of kosher salt on top. Let this hang out in the sink for approx. 30 min to drain and then used clean kitchen towel and squeezed out the remaining moisture. I diced the onion very small to make sure it was tender in the short cook time and used 1/4 cup flour and 1/4 cup Italian bread crumbs. Perfect. Grandbaby, young adults, teens, hubby, everyone loved them and insist that we at least double the recipe next time. Thanks for sharing!

Very yummy, very easy.  My kids weren't crazy about them but my husband & I thought they were fantastic.  After I mixed everything, the batter seemed really loose so I added a bit of extra flour (few Tbs.)  It still didn't hold but when I dropped big spoonfuls into my hot cast iron skillet, they stayed together.  I just patted flat with the back of spoon & flipped when golden brown.  I only used 2 Tbs. oil for the whole bunch.  Delicious!  And they really do look like the crispy brown cakes in photo.

text:
I made these zucchini patties as a side dish for tonight's dinner and got nothing but rave reviews from everyone at the table. After grating the zucchini I used a clean cotton dishtowel and squeezed the excess moisture out which helps keep the zucchini from becoming mushy in the middle. I did tweak the recipe up a little by finely chopping the onions, added 2 cloves of minced garlic, a little black pepper along with the salt and substituted dried potato flakes instead of flour. I did used olive oil to fry them in and they came out perfect. This recipe is definitely a keeper and will be making these as often as I have zucchini.

text:
I really wanted to give these more than three stars. To make them a little healthier, I used whole wheat flour, 4 egg whites and lowfat mozzerella cheese. I also used one whole leek that I'd bought at Trader Joe's the day before. These were a pain in the behind to cook. I didn't use any oil or butter, just cooked them on my griddle. First couple I made they were WAY too wet to cook right so I had to add another 1/4 c. of whole wheat flour. Then, they did cook up firm but weren't what I was hoping for. My husband and I thought these weren't bad but my youngest kid who's normally picky about everything I make INHALED these (and I did fib, I will be honest.....I told them they were Pizza Pancakes!) and asked for seconds. I took a couple other reviewer's suggestion and served it with a marinara sauce (The Best Marinara Sauce Yet, which is also from this site.) I think this has potential and I would love to make them again but I want to play with the recipe. Maybe add some spices next time. Good base recipe and I love that my picky youngest inhaled it. Thanks for sharing.

city:

country:
None
text:
This is our favorite zucchini recipe because it is very good in addition to being pretty quick and easy. I also feel it is more nutritious than zucchini bread. I have made it many many times over the past few years. A few of my recommendations: Hold the salt because the cheeses are salty and only add salt at the table if necessary. I added the salt in my first batch and it was way too salty for us. I prefer to use small zucchini as they have a better texture and flavor than the large ones. I fry these in coconut oil because it is not hydrogenated like shortening and gives food a crispier outside than oil does.

text:
Making these for the third time in as many weeks.  Everyone loves them.  I did substitute cheddar cheese for the mozzarella - I didn't have any mozzarella and we really like cheddar.  I think this may have added extra flavor.  I also added garlic, because we eat garlic in just about everything.  One night, I added fresh basil, because it was on the counter.  Other times I did not. We liked it both ways.  I used the exact ratios of flour, cheese & zuchini from the recipe.  It was just the right consistancy.  For those who are finding it too wet, if your zucchini is very large, try removing the seeds and pithy middle part before grating.  I have been using very fresh,  medium sized zucchini.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great base recipe for using up vegetables. I'm a fairly novice cook, but I popped half a zucchini, a patty pan squash, half an onion, and some garlic in the food processor (not all at once, of course) and then mixed that with some mozzarella (no parmesan on hand). Two eggs and 1/2 cup of flour seemed to be good to get the right consistency - you're looking for something that holds a heaping spoonful well. All I can say against it is that as is, it's bland. It definitely needs some salt, both to draw out moisture from the zucchini and for taste. I added some paprika, cayenne and black pepper to it, though you could take it any number of directions with a different spice combo.

text:
This was sooo good.Had a few minor adjustments. First I peeled the zucchini,the shredded it,let it drain for about 15 minuetes,then started putting everything together. I substituted garlic and herb bread crumbs instead of flour and kept everything else the same. I formed 10 patties and wasn't ready to cook them up yet, so I let them hang out on some parchment paper in the fridge for a couple hours. When I took them out, I just took some paper towel out to absorb any excess liquid. Instead of oilt to fry, I used butter flavor cookong spray. I also added a little bit more bread crumb to each patty. My husband almost ate all of it and he hates veggies.

text:
These were amazing!  Really really good.  I put in more zucchini than the recipe called for and I used dry TVP in place of the bread crumbs.  They don't change the taste and add lots of protine.  I added chopped red onions too.  The only problem I had was the mixture didn't hold well.  To fix it I mixed in the flour rather than dredging the patties.  I made a ton of them and froze them for future use.  They are such a good idea for all the extra garden zucchini that my boyfriend's country grandmother asked me for the recipe.

text:
These were good- but the recipe needed tweaking, namely the addition of spices (garlic, onion powder, red pepper, ground mustard). Used mashed potato flakes as suggested by other reviewers- I think this made a big difference in the consistency of the patties. We dipped the patties in sour cream. Not a super healthy side dish, but a good way to use a large amount of zucchini- I would make them again.

text:
good and easy recipe! my husband and daughter both enjoyed this. this time i used cheddar cheese instead of mozzerella an parmesan. i added a dash of red pepper flakes. to cut back on the fat, i sprayed a cookie sheet with pam, dropped the mixture on the sheet, dusted the tops with a little corn meal and resprayed the tops with pam.  i baked them for about 20 min. at 400degrees, then finished them under the broiler to crisp them up, turning over halfway through the broiling. wonderful. my daughter used hers like a soft open faced burrito, putting shredded lettuce, chopped tomatoe, onions, taco sauce. she loved it!

text:
I made these after finding a great price on zucchini at the market.  I didn't have any parmesan cheese, but added a combination of mozzarella and monterrey jack.  As per the suggestion of another reviewer, I added extra onion, and squeezed the excess water from the zucchini by placing it all in a clean cotton towel and twisting it up until the extra water dripped out.  This actually needs very little oil in the pan, which is great.  I topped them with a little kosher salt and they were yummy even without any other toppings!

I've made this recipe many times now, my whole family loves them. Most recently I needed something vegetarian to serve at a family dinner. I had these leftover from a previous meal so I topped them with pasta sauce, some parmesan and shredded mozzerella, heated it at 350 F. for about 20 min. and served them with pasta on the side. My vegetarian family members loved it! Thanks again for this recipe! 7/21/03Really great taste... the whole family ate these up! The only change I made was to substitute cheddar cheese for the mozerella because that was what was on hand. Will definitely make these again.

text:
I had to give it a 3 for kid rating because I have no idea how kids would react to it, my daughters are too young to appreciate the flavour!
This recipe is GREAT! I do highly recommend that you wring all possible water out of the zucchinis. I do this by wrapping them in a clean tea towel and squeezing as much water I can. I also found that making this recipe in advance and leaving it in the fridge 1 hour or more, enhances the flavour.
I will DEFINITELY be making that one again, and again, and again!

text:
Yum! This is now a favorite in our house even with the kids and I'm asked to make it every week. They taste amazing! Make sure after you grate the zucchini that you soak up the extra moisture with paper towels or whatever you usually use for that. You need to get rid of the excess water before you cook these. I used mostly zucchini and then one squash. Because other people said it tastes kind of bland with just the 1/2 cup of flour, I seasoned the mix with garlic powder, smoked paprika, and salt and pepper.

Tammy Lynn

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3542952.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've never made any zucchini patties/cakes before. I burned the first batch and had to clean out the pan and start over! However, the rest of them came out fine after I made some adjustments. To start, the recipe should state that you need to drain and squeeze out most of the water from the zucchini. I added about 1/4 c of potato flakes because the first batch was too runny. I really liked the flavor the potato flakes gave it. I also added some garlic powder and a little Italian seasoning. These really cook better when they are small and you only use a heaping tablespoon of batter as the recipe states. The first batch I tried to make too big. Also, next time I won't put the whole 2 T of oil in at once. The directions indicate to just put a "small amount of oil," and they cooked much better once I cleaned out the pan and just put about a tsp or so in. Then I added a bit more oil before cooking each batch. DH and I liked these with hot sauce on top, served with hummus and veggies and some cut up watermelon.

None
text:
This recipe was so good! I have a few minor tips to add: 1) use "drained" ziccini (shred it and salt it to remove a lot of water then give it a rinse to remove any surface salt) and do not add extra salt to the batter and 2) use a 1/4 cup measure (or smaller!) or disher to measure out the zuccini-batter as it is very soft and easy to flip/fold over onto itself and a smaller patty flips better.

text:
With a couple of adjustments based on other reviews, the result was a super delicious, super healthy meal that I will definitely be making again in the future! I subbed the flour with bread crumbs. I didn't have any Italian bread crumbs as others suggested, so I used plain ones and added Italian seasoning. I used a low fat 4 cheese Italian blend for my cheeses because it's what I had on hand, and added a bit of garlic powder to the mixture. I also made sure to squeeze the excess moisture out of the zucchini as many others suggested. To cut back on fat I baked the patties on a non-stick pan at 375 degrees for 10 minutes on each side. Hubby made a face when I told him I'd made a veggie meal for lunch, but changed his mind after his first bite!

text:
Made these the first time exactly how it says too except I added shredded carrots. Second time i made them was two days later and this time I added the carrots again and because I didn't have any garlic I added 1/2 a tsp of garlic powder & a squeeze of lime some black pepper and little bit of salt. There are a lot of reviews saying theirs was to runny...the only thing I can figure is they were useing oversized zucchini that were all seeds. My zucchinis were straight from the garden and were maybe 7 inches long 2 1/2 inches around. The mix was nice and thick not runny at all. Going to make them a third time in a couple of weeks for my church potluck.

I thought these tasted really good! I have another go to recipe for zucchini patties, but wanted to test this recipe. This one has a little more cheese and the added onion. I thought it would take longer to make then it did, but it was actually really fast. They cook up real quickly to. I grated two kinds of small zucchinis and I ended up with 2 cups really packed when measured, and it worked fine. I also grated my own mozzarella cheese. I was only able to get 9 patties, instead of the 12, but I am the only one eating them anyway. I might try butter instead of oil next time as that is what I have always used, when I made them, and they normally seem a little less greasy. Either way, this made a nice lunch today and I may even have it for dinner.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/791040.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make zucchini patties often, but this recipe looked so much better than mine that I decided to try it.  I made a number of alterations (mostly based on other reviews), but the recipe was such a great base that I still had to give it 4 stars!  My husband gobbled these down and said they were *much* better than my original ones!  Here's what I did: Replaced 1/4 cup flour with one slice of bread's worth of fresh, toasted breadcrumbs; added an additional 2 oz. shredded carrot to the mix for color and flavor; added 2 large cloves of fresh pressed garlic; added 1 tbs. salt-free Italian-seasoning plus 1/8 tsp. red pepper flakes and 1/8 tsp. fennel; and used basil-&-tomato-seasoned feta cheese in place of the parmesan.  I salted the zucchini and allowed it to drain in my collander in the sink for 30 minutes, then squeezed out the excess moisture.  I will be making these all the time now, for breakfast and dinner both.

text:
Good base for a recipe, but you definitely want to add flavor or these patties are very bland.  I chopped up the zucchini in a small dice instead of grating so you could taste it, also added a diced tomato (seeded w/as little juice as possible), also added garlic salt (real garlic if you have it) and onion powder as well as a big squirt of Sriracha (be careful it's hotttt).  With the larger zucchini the texture was much better, but didn't hold together as well.  Also dipped in a tiny bit of Sriracha to eat.  Next time I will add red bell pepper.

text:
These are delicious.  I am only rating it 4 stars because I made a lot modifications, but I would rate my final product 5 stars.  I grated my zucchini and then spun it in the salad spinner to get rid of excess liquid (I emptied the liquid out of the salad spinner twice, and the zucchini was still plenty wet.  I used 1/2 cup of Italian bread crumbs and 2 tablesoons flour instead of 1/2 cup of flour.  I also added a generous grinding of pepper, and 3 cloves of garlic, minced.  I dropped a "ball" of the mixture into additional breadcrumbs, and patted it flat to look more like a patty, coated all sides in the bread crumbs and fried in the pan.  My husband LOVED them.

text:
I really loved these. I made them with Extra Sharp Cheddar cheese because that's what I had on hand, and they were excellent. The recipe is extrememly versatile I think, so you could modify it if you like, and I'm sure most modifications will be tasty (although the recipe is great in its original formula!) 

The batter surprisingly held together really well, I didn't have any problems with them falling apart. My only problem was that they were still slightly soft on the inside, so next time I think I'll make the patties a bit smaller.

For those that freeze these, how do you reheat them? Thanks!

text:
We basically liked this recipe but it was not spicy enough to suit us.  To the recipe below we added 2 fresh (shredded) jalapeno peppers, 1 heaping tablespoon minced garlic, 1 teaspoon coarsely ground pepper, and 1/2 onion (chopped).  We used 1/2 cup whole wheat flour in place of all-purpose flour, and 3 egg whites instead of whole eggs.  That gave it some kick!

text:
These are wonderful...although I did make a few changes...After shredding, I patted excess water out with paper towels.  I added cornmeal (for crunch) and bread crumbs along with the flour.  I also added shredded carrots (for color) and chopped fresh parsley, along with grated romano, cheddar and mozzarella cheeses).  I skipped the salt and used pepper.  I formed patties then added additional bread crumbs/cornmeal to get the right consistency.  I patted additional breadcrumbs on them before browning in olive oil.  With the three cheeses and additional changes, they were packed with flavor.

text:
Like others suggested I added salt to grated zucchini and left in colander to remove the excess moisture. Mixed in black pepper and 1 garlic clove (no more than 1). Put in fridge until I was ready to use. I only had cheddar cheese to use. Sooooo yummy!!!
Next time I'll cut down on raw onion and garlic as I'm feeling quite garlicky and oniony after this.


Next time:
1. Can substitute flour with instant potato flakes or whole wheat flour. (I wonder if I could just add a boiled potato instead)
2. Add any other veg. - grated carrots, yellow squash or red bell pepper.
3. If I don't have cheese it's still good.
4. Add Italian style bread crumbs to mixture and coat patty before frying.
5. Can fry, broil, grill or bake
6. Serve w marinara sauce or sour cream w chives
7. Things you can add to mix up - mushrooms, parsley, fresh dill, pesto, red pepper flakes
(Not good for freezing - tastes bland once thawed)

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
These were excellent! I made a few changes based on the reviews. I soaked the shredded zucchini in salted water for a few minutes and then drained it in a strainer. I then squeezed the rest of the liquid out by wrapping the zucchini in a paper towel and ringing it out. Instead of the 1/2 cup of flour, I used 1 Tbsp of flour and 1/2 cup of Panko breadcrumbs, I had pre-shredded nacho cheese blend, so I used that instead of mozzarella. I also added salt, pepper, oregano and garlic powder. I served it with marinara sauce for dipping. They were delicious! If I didn't put the zucchini in myself, I wouldn't have known I was eating a vegetable. I will definitely be making them again.

4 stars as written but with a few tweaks it's a 5! 
Definitely squeeze out excess moisture from zucchini, and if your kids have an aversion to all things green like mine do, peel the zucchini first! Potato flakes are the way to go instead of flour and garlic and onion powder help amp up the flavor. 
They are great for a quick breakfast, pull them out of the freezer and reheat in a a super hot toaster oven for a crispy, quick breakfast!

userID:
8732153
Display Name:
happydays
isPro:
False
followersCount:
6
followingCount:

22
favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is very good.  I did substitute jack cheese for the mozzarella.  I assembled the mix a little different.  I did drain the zucchini after I shredded it in the food processor.  Just a few paper towels in a glass pie plate, changing a couple of times.  I placed the zucchini in a mixing bowl with the diced onion and flour.  I mixed w/a fork to coat the zucchini.  Then I added the Parmesan cheese and mixed again.  I then added the shredded cheese and mixed one more time. I added the beaten eggs and all came together just fine.  I cooked these in a large non-stick skillet with a little peanut oil.  I used a soup spoon and a fork for dropping into the skillet, and then I spread them out a bit.  Wait till they firm up before trying to flip or they will fall apart.  When you see the edges beginning to turn golden, take a look and if the bottom is golden and firm, gently flip over to cook the other side.  I could do four at a time, and I placed them on a cookie rack to drain. I had wax paper and paper towels below it to catch any drippings. This is when I added the sea salt for flavoring.  Adding salt to the mix will only cause the zucchini to weep more water.  These can be kept warm on the rack in the oven with a cookie sheet below it to catch any drippings.  All in all, a very easy recipe to prepare, and I believe these can be cooled and frozen on a cookie sheet over night, then individually wrapped, & frozen in the FoodSaver bag.
Just reheat in oven & serve. ThkU Sherlie

I did NOT salt/drain the zucchini - No problem.  We topped it with a blend freshly chopped tomato and basil, salt and pepper, and an olive oil drizzle.  Yum!

text:
I made these today and they were delicious.  This is a great bisic recipe that can be tweaked to your individual tastes.  Based on some reviewer suggestions, I substituted sharp cheddar for the mozarella cheese and used panko crumbs intead of flour. I also added a couple of jalapeno (seeded) peppers finely chopped.  After they got crispy, I moved them to layers of paper towel and also patted them on top to soak up excess oil.  I served them with spicy salsa (I like spice).  A great way to use up this plentiful vegetable in the summer.

I processed the fresh zuchinni in my food processor and put it in a bowl with paper towel on the bottom for a day to draw out the excess moisture.  The zuchinni was given to me by a co-worker.  This is a keeper and give it five thumbs up!!!

These are AMAZING.  No, really.  They're out of this world and I don't give a recommendation like that lightly.  I did remove the excess moisture from the zucchini by lightly salting it and pressing between paper towels.  I upped the mozzarella to about 3/4 cup and added about 1/2 c bread crumbs, 2 tsp of minced garlic and 1 tsp of oregano.  I tried making the patties the same size as the recipe states as well as making larger ones, and I'd stick with small ones.  Served with marinara and parmesan.  Will be making this a LOT!

These were fantastic! I made them so my vegetarian hubby would have something to eat at our last party. I was so rushed I forgot to make a sauce or garnish so it was served plain, but EVERYONE (even my 3 and 4 year old) loved them! They were all eaten immediately, I wish I had made a double or triple recipe! People were literally hounding me the next day to send them the recipe. I made it exactly as written except I used a Romano and Parmesan blend instead of just Parmesan. I don't have a food processor so I used a cheese grater to grate the zucchini. It was fast, easy, and simple to clean up. This was so easy to make and so delicious! Thank you so much for sharing this recipe!!!

text:
Quite enjoyable, and very easy to make! My only suggestions is to drain the squash and use panko breadcrumbs instead of the flour. It's really fine with the flour, but the panko just gives it a different texture that I tend to like. Finally, don't be afraid to adjust the seasonings to your liking. It's a very flexible recipe.

text:
I followed the recipe because I'm a firm believer in not tweaking it until after I've made it once.  I measured and did not eyeball any of the ingredients and had to add extra eggs to get everything incorporated.  I urge everyone to make one pattie, taste it then adjust for salt and consider adding pepper as they are on the bland side.  My mother made something similar and I lost her recipe over the years and this one is the closest to hers.  They were a big hit as a side dish and there wasn't one left and I doubled the recipe.  All in all it's a 5 star recipe.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easy and delicious. I salted the shredded zucchini and let it sit in a colander for 10 minutes to soften and drain, then squeezed out extra water. Added 1/4 cup of flour and 1/4 cup of bread crumbs. Go light on the garlic and the onions, otherwise they will overpower the lightness of the other flavors. We topped the patties with homemade bruschetta and they were fantastic. These would be a great addition for brunch, instead of hashbrowns or home fries. If these freeze and reheat well (I have a few test patties in the freezer) this recipe may be the answer to the glut of zucchini from our garden...

text:
The flavor is great, but the "batter" is quite thin when following this recipe as-is.  In fact, I added bread crumbs to the recipe & it was STILL too thin.  The trick is probably in salting & draining the grated zucchini before use.  I found also that refrigerating the batter & dropping fairly small amounts of batter into the pan helped them cook through & be more manageable.  Again, very tasty; served with tzatziki sauce.

text:
These were good. I  made them for a party so I quadrupled the recipe - 8 cups zucchini, 6 eggs, 1 cup onion, 1 cup flour, 1 cup seasoned breadcrumbs, 2 cups parmesan, 2 cups mozzarella, 2 tsp. kosher salt, pepper, fresh parsley and 4 cloves minced garlic as per suggestions by other reviewers. I made them on my electric griddle drizzled with a little olive oil to save time and excess oil. They came out great. I made them ahead of time and froze them. I plan to pop them in the oven to reheat and serve them with marinara.

text:
I made this following the recipe pretty carefully, but I decided to bake them instead of frying them in a pan. It didn't work *quite* as well, but it wasn't a failure. I baked the patties on a cookie sheet in a 400 degree oven, turning every 5-8 minutes, until browned. they didn't come out crispy, but they were good. The next day, I reheated some leftovers in the toaster oven using the "toast" setting, and they were much better.

This is a very good recipe which I will definitely use again. After reading other reviews, I made a couple adjustments. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So good and easy! Read the other reviews, made a few minor changes/additions and served with "best marinara sauce yet" from this site. I used 1/4 C wheat flour, 1/4 C seasoned breadcrumbs, 1/2 t garlic powder, fresh parsley and 1 shallot. Last season I had shredded giant zucchinis and froze them in 3 C portions. Now all I had to do was take 1 bag out, put in colander and put under hot water to thaw it very quickly. Then squeeze the moisture out and it was ready. My 3 year-old and 18-month-old kids loved this for dinner.

text:
I did what other reviewers suggested and salted the zucchini, washed it out and then squeezed it dry with a potato ricer, making the zucchini much easier to work with.  I also added garlic powder and black pepper to combat the blandness.  Although it tasted ok, I didn't like the end texture of this patty - it felt kind of gummy and too cheesy.  I think if I ever make these again, I will use bread crumbs as well to give it a more solid texture and try to flatten them as much as possible.

text:
I don't know why everyone is trying to make these stay together or is worried about mixture being too wet. They are supposed to be dropped by spoonfuls onto a hot griddle, like pancakes, not shaped like crab cakes. I followed the recipe exactly and we LOVED them. This is the best "what to do with all that zucchini" recipe I have seen. I have also experimented with using peeled eggplant instead, and it tastes even BETTER. I have also used Old Cheddar instead of mozzerella. I have a bunch frozen for quick lunches. Will probably try adding garlic or Italian seasoning next time.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe has to be played with a lot. Spices are a must. I added a bunch of garlic, pepper and paprika. I did drain the zucchini but still had to use more bread crumbs and flour than the recipe called for. Eventually it ended up being pretty good with sour cream on top. I felt the italian bread crumbs left a funny aftertaste, next time I'll try flour and instant mashed potatoes like one person suggested. You have to make them small so they'll flip without falling apart (in a non stick skillet), I used cooking spray instead of oil and that worked just fine.

text:
I followed the recipe exactly except I added fresh ground black pepper and a little garlic powder.  The mix did seem to get watery as I went on, next time I may sprinkle zucchini w/salt ahead of time, drain, & then fry.  The trick to them staying together was to spread them thin, and not flip until golden brown on bottom, then turn.  The thicker ones were mushy inside.  But a good idea for zucchini.

text:
The recipe I created for zucchini patties, contains some potato flakes which does keep them together better, also try adding some herbs like chopped parsley, or oregano.You can also try baking these in a cookie sheet and cutting into fingers for dipping. These are good with pizza sauce, or yogurt dill dip. Also try using a blender or chopper to get the zucchini finer otherwise you may get a stringy texture, the sane goes for carrot cakes.

text:
This has become a family favorite for both me and my daughter's family. We use the recipe as is but also add variations such as different kinds of crumbs instead of flour. We also add herbs and spices such as cinnamon and nutmeg if we want a sweeter taste or italian seasonings or greek seasonings if we want a less sweet taste. We have even tried it adding a teaspoon of hot chili oil to the recipe and like that too. We have used gravy, sauces and fruit syrups. We love this. Our four zucchini plants are having a hard keeping up with the demand.

text:
As suggested by another reviewer, I baked them at 375 for 20 minutes and flipped and baked another 15. Also used 1 T flour and 1/3c Italian bread crumbs. I only had about 1/3c pepper jack cheese and a small bit of left over feta but suspect would be with any kind of cheese on hand. I shredded the zuc then squeezed out water then packed into measuring cup until I got 2c. I got about 5 cakes out of the mix. I am freezing 2 to see how they hold up to a quick thaw for a quick breakfast.

text:
Really like these. One batch made 6 large, palm sized patties. Very versatile, allowing lots of options for what you would like to add. The recipe is 5 stars because its a wonderful base. These came out firm, browned up nicely, and i froze them. The oil in my pan is Coconut oil. which browned them up great. Also BIG TIP - I wrapped the shredded zucchini in papertowls for a few hours which i think really helped control the water level. will be making these again.

text:
I'd forgotten how wet of a vegetable zucchini was until today. It's been a long, long, long time since I cooked it b/c my husband doesn't care for it. Hwr, after years of refusals, he laid out half-a-row of the garden we plant with my MIL to seed zucchini for me. It had been so long since I made zucchini patties that I had to look up a recipe. (outright embarrassing) This was the closest to my late mom's recipe & the one I'd memorized so long ago. 

Not sure how it happened but our 21yo daughter actually loved it & came back for 2nds & 3rds! It needed a bit more salt, which I forgot to add before putting in the eggs & flour, so it wasn't to taste. Still turned out well. Hubby even had 2nds too!  Great recipe! Thanks for helping me bring a bit of Mom back into my life after so many years without her. I'll be making more & remembering to pick up paper towels to better dry the zucchini before mixing.

None
text:
Can this recipe be adapted for baking?
Great recipe, but don't make the mistakes I made
1. I didn't drain the chopped zucchini before I mixed the ingredients, so I had to add a lot of Italian bread crumbs to dry up the mix.
2. I started frying with olive oil, thinking it would add flavor. But it burned at too low a temperature, and so did the patties. When I switched to canola oil the patties sauted just fine. Golden brown instead of black!

i have been making this for years but had lost my recipe. I remembered that I used to add cornmeal instead of flour, liked the texture better.  I used the one suggestion of adding some potato flakes, which I did tonight & liked them even better.I used half flakes & half cornmeal.  I cooked four for my son before adding the onion because onion upsets his tummy. Then I added the onion & cooked the rest. I cooked mine using coconut oil on an electric griddle at 400 deg. This is a versatile recipe which give room for lots of variations. We serve with a dash of soy sauce. We have used left overs for sandwich in stead of bread

text:
I did make a few changes. I used grated BelGioioso  parmesan and and provolone cheeses. I sprayed my griddle with Pam instead of oil mostly because I didn't want the zucchini to soak up too much oil. Also, I used my own homegrown zucchini. I had it frozen from last year and drained it and then used my salad spinner to take some of the extra moisture out. I did not chop it. Served with sour cream, it is delicious! I'd make it again. It's easy and makes a great snack.

text:
I decided to go on a ten day meat fast and needed a recipe for some zucchini I had in the fridge. I followed the recipe with these few changes. I added one tablespoon of minced garlic, and some chopped cilantro to the mixture. I also added a dash of Old Bay, lemon pepper and 21 Salute seasoning from trader Joe's. I didn't use any salt and instead of two eggs I used one extra large brown egg. Once they were finished I topped them of with marinera sauce. They were delish!

5572299
Display Name:
Terri

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Instead of using a grater, I ran the zucchini through the food processor to a course chop, then squeezed it out as much as possible in a kitchen towel before mixing with the other ingredients.  I will chop them ahead of time next time to allow more time for the liquid to drain off.   As suggested by other reviewers, I added garlic - A LOT of garlic - and substituted 1/2 of the flour with seasoned breadcrumbs, but otherwise followed the recipe.   Having not read the directions completely, I tried to pat these out like you would a tuna patty, and that clearly was not going to happen (it was quite "runny").  Once I noticed the direction to drop it in the pan by the spoonful, they began to cook up nicely and the runny consistency was no problem.  I think if you made them without seasoning them generously, they would be bland, but being forewarned by other reviewers, I went heavy with the garlic and black pepper, and used about 1/2 tsp (approx) of salt, and they were delicious.  Another Meatless Monday hit!  I am eager to try some of the other reviewers' variations  (like potato flakes for flour).

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
**EDITED: to add that the next morning, I had a couple of these patties left over so  I refried them in a little butter to warm and dipped them into plain yogurt (sour cream would be same) for breakfast, and they were awesome! **

The flavor of these was very good. I did add a little chopped red bell pepper simply because I had one I wanted to use up, and it tasted very good in there. The only issue I had was the texture of the mixture was a little hard to work with. It was fairly gloppy (even after following the suggestion to salt and "bleed" the zucchini before using), and I really wanted to get a little breading (panko + italian breadcrumbs) onto the outside of them. I ended up sprinkling breading on a plate, spooning out a blob of mixture, and then sprinkling breading on top. It was a sloppy process to then transfer that to the hot pan. However, they held together just fine for flipping and then serving. I served them with warmed jarred marinara from Costco (my fav because it's delicious and has no sugar). My family liked them a lot. I'll make them again, but I'll toy with the ratios a bit to see if I can make them easier to manage.

text:
These are great! This is the third time I've made them with these modifications:  Reduce flour to 1/4 c. and don't salt until they come out of the frying pan.  I have never drained the zucchini or had an issue with wetness.  I do add:  2 Tbs. of chopped jalapenos (sliced from a jar),  2 sliced green onions (white and green),  1 cold baked potato, peeled and grated, and 1/4 tsp. baking powder.  Cook nice and golden and salt to taste.  They're the bomb!

Casablancaise

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7503916.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love these patties. I have been making for years and got many requests for the recipe.
My way of getting rid of the zucchini juice is quite simple and efficient. I use the larger hole side of the box grater. I grate the zucchinis ( 2 medium size ones ) on a plate that I double line with paper towels ( good quality kind, not the cheap stuff) and wrap the paper towels around the zucchini shreds and press with my hands until the juice stops  coming out. Then, I mix all the ingredients in a bowl but don't add the salt (3/4 teaspoon is the right amount for my taste) until just before starting to fry the patties. I use a small cookie scoop to drop the mixture in the pan and the back of the scoop to flatten that little bit.
I sometime like to add some herbs, about 1/4 teaspoon of dried thyme or dried dill. Yum !

text:
We grow lots of zucchini.  I'm always looking for good recipes to use it fresh.   My only  ingredient change was instead of salt, I added 3/4 tsp. garlic pepper (the blend I have includes salt). Drain zucchini after grating, and everything will come together well.   I did not drop these into the pan, instead, I spread the batter into the pan all at once, pressing it thin, and really let it brown before I flipped it.  I then cooked it to a golden on the underside, on med. low.  This was mainly because I didn't want to attend to all the little patties, and it came out really delicious.  I cut it like a pie in the frying pan and served it up.  Kids and husband wished I had a second pan.  Salsa is a great topper for this.

text:
This is an essential recipe; the reason being is that the RATIO of the ingredients are right.  When you tweek it, remember that the dry flour and egg is how it is held together so if you put extra stuff in it you need to increase egg and flour accordingly. It should look like a sticky batter that holds its shape.  Also, as many other reviewers mentioned, it is a must to put the shredded zucchini in a strainer with salt and let the water seep out. Then squeeze and press the bejesus out of it and for good measure use paper towel to push more water out.  This will ensure success.

country:

text:
They were OK, I'd eat them again but they aren't the kind of food I would crave. Definitely more a side dish or appetizer than a main dish. I agree with other reviewers in that they can be tastier if you add more flavorful ingredients like flavored bread crumbs, potato flakes, or herbs and spices. One thing to beware: the fresh zucchini doesn't cook much during the frying process. The frying mostly just melts the cheese and sets the egg. Eating fresh zucchini causes gas and bloating because the cellulose isn't weakened yet like it is after a thorough cooking. When your body digests cellulose the by-product is methane gas. I was intensely uncomfortable the evening after we had these with dinner. I recommend limiting consumption to 1-3 patties at one sitting.

country:
None
text:
The key to making successful patties that don't turn to mush is to SPIRALIZE the zucchini.  DO NOT put them in food processor.  Keeping them in spaghetti like strands will ensure quick cooking, without falling apart or taking a long time frying.  Once you make them correctly you can increase/tweak the ingredients to suit your taste.  Definitely worth making again if you blended the zucchini the first time around.  Great with spaghetti meat on top, or scrambled eggs, or chicken, or even as buns for turkey burgers.  So versatile!  This one's definitely a keeper in our house!

text:
Pretty good recipe and probably would have been good as is except for we like spicy food around here and have dietary restrictions, thanks. However, I'm not sure how this would have turned out if I hadn't squeezed the water out of the zucchini first. I have a gluten free house, so I took advice from one of the earlier posts and used instant mashed potatoes in place of flour and put in one tablespoon of baking powder. I also microplaned two cloves of garlic and finely chopped two tablespoons of onion and one whole poblano pepper into the mix. One last addition: 1 teaspoon each of garlic and onion power, and 1/2 teaspoon of cayenne pepper. Everyone loved it -- I probably should have doubled the recipe. Oh and I used plain yogurt instead of sour cream, which I added a squirt of lemon juice, some dill, cayenne pepper, and some garlic and onion powder.

1
userID:
4077626
Display Name:
MsXmas
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
626
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As written the ingredients are a good base allowing you to be as creative as your palate would prefer. 

My tweaks: I used 5 cups of shredded zucchini. Mixed it in a bowl with a bit of kosher salt then poured it into a colander to drain for an hour.  In a food processor I put about 12 baby carrots, 2 cloves of garlic, 1 small red onion, an assortment of 8 luncheon size red, yellow and orange peppers. I pulsed the veggies several times and then put those into a tea towel to squeeze out excess moisture and put the veggies in a mixing bowl. Then I squeezed the excess water from the zucchini in the same way and added it to the veggies. 

To the bowl I added Italian bread crumbs and instant potato flakes, Italian seasoning, a bit of black pepper and paprika.  I added about 1 cup of fiesta mix shredded cheese and 1/2 cup of fresh shredded asiago cheese and finally 3 beaten eggs. Mixed it all well and placed the bowl in the fridge to chill for about an hour.

I lined 2 half sheet pans with parchment and sprayed with olive oil Pam. I formed the mix into burger size patties, covered one side with a mix of panko and grated Parmesan and placed the panko side down on the tray. I patted the panko mix on the top side of each of the 13 burgers and then sprayed each with the olive oil Pam.

These baked in a 375 degree oven for about 40 minutes flipping 1/2 way through.

The family loved them with sour cream. There were 3 of us and only 4 of the 13 burger size patties were left after dinner.

text:
My 6 and 3 year old children LOVED these!!  I did make a few changes after reading the other reviews. I added an extra egg but I think I had more that 2 cups zucchini anyways (i didn't measure). I used green onions instead of white because that is what I had on hand but would do it again since I like the texture better, used a mix of bisquick and panko bread crumbs instead of white flour and added garlic.  Served it with a side of pizza sauce!  To make it dairy free for my son who has an allergy, I separated the mixture before adding the cheese and used Trader Joes VEGAN mozzarella shreds and cooked his first.  Will make this recipe again and again!!

text:
The only reason I gave this recipe three stars was due to the texture- I don't know what I did wrong- but I'm going to have to try this one again sometime. The flavor is great, and they did cook into nice patties, ( though there was no way I would be able to form them into patties before placing them on the griddle,) but the inside was very mushy, even after they had been cooked for a good amount of time. I squeezed out as much moisture from the chopped veggies as I could, and even added a little more flour...maybe I used too much flour? In any case, although I couldn't get the texture right this time, the flavor was nice enough that I will try again!

country:
None
text:
I made these for dinner tonight.  I had made them exactly as written before and would rate them that way as a three.  This time I read all the other reviews and the only change I made was to drain the salted zucchini for a few hours then pat dry, and substituted an equal amount of seasoned italian bread crumbs for the flour.  This makes them MUCH better, they hold together and crisp up better.  Mine really does look like the ones in the picture with the cherry tomatoes and I would serve them that way next time for a light lunch.  We ate them with a chicken sausage and mushroom ragout and a glass of the reisling I used in the ragout.  Delicious!

None
text:
I've made this several times with various cheeses and all are good.  One suggestion for the person who said the batter was too runny.  Wait until the last thing before adding the salt, or better, salt while frying.  Salt draws the moisture out of the zucchini.  If it's added too early, you can end up with a very liquid batter.

text:
I tried this recipe recently and I would strongly suggest that the zucchini is drained for 15 minutes before making the patties so that the patty mixture won't be soggy.  I added Italian dried herbs and garlic powder and used 1 tsp. Kosher salt.  I fried the patties in a mixture of 1/2 oil and 1/2 butter.  They tasted really good.

brhodes_6

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the advice of some of the other reviewers and used IDAHOAN potato flakes in place of the flour.  I also added an abundance of spices -- lots of garlic, salt, ground pepper and parsley.  I added some chopped crimini mushrooms and about 3/4 of an onion.  I used fresh parmesan but didn't have enough so substituted some romano and upped the mozza to 3/4 cup.  I found that after adding the listed ingredients, the mixture did not stick together well enough.  So, I added more potato flakes.  This did not help.  I ended up using 3 eggs and about 1- 1 1/2 cups of potato flakes just to get them to stick together.  The patties took a nice form but after the first bite, I wasn't wanting more! It was fairly flavorless, which was surprising considering the amount of spices I used!!  With a considerable amount more spices and less potato flakes (though I don't know how else you could get them to stick together) these could be good.  As for now, these are far too bland!

text:
Very easy to make, quick simple meal- going by other's suggestions, I squeezed the water out of the zukes first, sauteed chopped mushrooms with the onion before stirring into the batter.
They were very good as is, but still a bit bland for my taste, so next time I would add more herbs, probably basil, garlic chives- and up the mushrooms/onions. 
I topped with fresh marinara and parmesan- love the quickness and ease of this recipe, it's a keeper- my bf who doesn't care for zukes loved it!  I only got 6 cakes out of the recipe, we ate all of them!

My husband said he could eat this on a regular basis.  I substituted spelt flour for those of you allergic to wheat.

Ray's trick for frozen spinach of putting all the shredded zucch in a dish towel and twisted to drain.  did the 1 tbs flour and then used the ital. breadcrumbs.  sauteed the onion with a bunch of fresh garlic for a few minutes.  added red pepper flakes and served with an over-easy egg on top for breakfast.  this will become a regular, esp. in the summer when we have tons of zucch from the garden!  its a keeper!

text:
OMG!...I made these. and we just loved them. My husband dont like zucchini and he didntknow what they were, tried a bite and said they were really good what are they?  lol I made mine simple, squeezed all the water out after i shredded my zucchini. chopped a small onion added seasoning, garlic powder, lemon pepper and celery salt. about 4 tbsp or 5 of flour, was going to use bread crumbsbut was out, going to try it that way next time. One egg slightly beaten. They were still kinda moist but good enough to scoop up and lay into the skillet then i took my fork and flattened them. Med heat, and turned them over when they were a nice golden crispy brown and all i can say is yum yum yum!!! Our new favorite...Mix it up a lil, maybe green and red bell pepper . So many options..Enjoy people

Overall, this recipe was good. I had a hard time finding the right amount of olive oil to fry these in. Too much made them too greasy, and too little made them burn. The taste was good, both fresh and cold. Applesauce on top added a little extra kick. I made these two weekends in a row which was overkill, so I would have to limit making these to special occasions.

text:
I thought these patties had great flavor, but were a little more like a pancake than I had hoped for. I was looking for more of a hash brown/crab cake consistency, but they were very doughy instead. Next time I think I'll omit 2 of the eggs and see what happens. Overall a good recipe though!

UPDATE: made these again using only one egg and got a much better hash-browny texture. Definitely a keeper!

text:
Really good!! After reading the reviews I did what others said.   salted and wrung out the zucchini - added a bit more once wrung out to bulk up the dish. 1/4 cup flour 2 annehiem peppers diced for heat  Fresh parsley diced 1/2 large onion 5 cloves garlic pepper  (cheese wise i used what was on hand - shredded "Mexican/Jack blend" and freshly grated Parm.)   mixed everything then made patties and rolled them in italian bread crumbs.   Heated the pan, added a little olive oil to coat the pan then cooked them till brown.   Served with fat free sour cream & choula hot sauce.   We also tried it with a sundried tomato pesto.. but that didnt taste as good.   **Although yummy - it did make quite a bit of mess for such a simple dish. I am going to play with it a bit more.. needs a few more spices or something to make it outstanding.

text:
I've been making something like this for years called "Pizza Squash"; only without the mozzarella but more like 3/4 cup grated parmesan, and I use about 4 cups of shredded zucchini, and used finely grated onion, 1/2 tsp garlic powder, 1 tsp dried basil, 1 tsp dried oregano, 1/4 tsp ground thyme for seasoning, and I use closer to 1 cup of flour or until about the consistency of biscuit dough.  I brown them in 1 T of margarine with 1 T of olive oil.  This makes a lot but the leftovers are even better!

Display Name:
Diane

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I grew up eating my Italian Mother & Grandmother's squash patties! Draining the salted, grated, zucchini in a colander (use a heavy weight on top of a plate) for several hours is a must! Use lots of grated romano cheese, salt, pepper and granulated garlic for a nice flavor (red pepper flakes are optional). I use a scant 1/4 cup measure to scoop the batter and flatten slightly once in  the hot oil (always use light olive oil) so they are not too thick and cook through. I even sprinkle very lightly with kosher salt or more grated romano immediately after removing from the olive oil and placing on paper towel to drain.

text:
Very good...We had them for dinner and dipped them in marinara sauce.  Would make a great appetizer too.  My almost 1 year old liked them surprisingly, and my 3 year old ate them up!  Like others, I substituted 1/4 c. seasoned bread crumbs for 1/4 c. of the flour, and added a clove of minced fresh garlic and pepper.   I got impatient waiting for the zucchini to dry out in the collander and just squeezed it by hand instead.  I fried the patties in olive oil instead of vegetable for flavor and flattened them out a bit in the pan as they were cooking.  I ended up with 7 and it was just enough for me and my 2 kids :)  I'll double it next time if my husband is eating too!  Oh, and next time I'd try adding some diced mushrooms to the mixture.

country:
None
text:
This is a great simple recipe which can be modified and enhanced in many ways.  As other reviews mentioned you should try to extract as much liquid from the zucchini as possible before mixing with the other ingredients.  If you don't have enough people to eat the whole recipe at one meal, just put the batter in the fridge.  A day or two later you can make them again and maybe add a new twist as I did by adding some fried sausage bits or whatever leftover cooked meat you have on hand.  Herbs are a good addition too, I added fresh basil to mine.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent vegetarian recipe, high in protein. To lighten up the fat content, I used 1/4 cup grated asiago, 1/2 cup fat-free shredded mozzarella, and 1/2 cup organic egg whites. I grated both 1 med zucchini and 1 med vidalia, squeezing out much of the liquid. I used 1/2 cup organic whole grain pastry flour, and 1/2 tsp Crazy Jane's Mixed-up salt. The yield was 12 2 1/2-3" pancakes. We enjoyed these as a main course with salad, homemade applesauce, french bread and a crisp Pinot Gris. Better than a restaurant! Having worked in the restaurant business 30 years, I know what goes on behind the scenes, and with a good recipe, quality ingredients, and good company, it's almost always better at home. 'Specially for vegetarians. Thanks, Sherlie! Will be using this recipe often.

text:
I make these all the time and as some other reviewers suggested, I use baking mix instead of flour. It adds a little saltiness and richness to the flavor and makes them even better. I also fry them in butter instead of oil -- it makes them a little less healthy, but just that much tastier;)  Another tip is to make sure you beat the egg nice and fluffy before adding to the other ingredients. This makes the patties themselves lighter and fluffier. This is my go-to quick recipe (provided I have the ingredients on hand), my husband and I love them!

These were very light and tasty.  I did alter the recipe a little bit.  I used 1 med. zucchini and 1 med. summer squash and I squeezed a lot of water out of them. text:
Great recipe!  I added 1 tsp of Old Bay seasoning to give it some zip.  Also added garlic powder and onion powder.  Will try Cajun or taco seasoning in the future.  As another reviewer stated, this is a very forgiving recipe.  I used about 3 cups of zucchini, and replaced the flour with bread crumbs and a tablespoon of flour.  Used parmesan cheese & a shredded taco cheese blend.  The key is to squeeze the excess liquid out of the zucchini -- first by hand, then by wringing it in a clean dishtowel.

None
text:
I've made these several times, and every time I do they're a hit.  As soon as I fry them up, they disappear!  Living in rural Virginia, we are lucky to have access to wonderful produce, and this is a great way to use up zucchini.  The only thing I would suggest is putting your grated zucchini in a clean dish towel, and wringing it out thouroughly before adding the other ingredients.  This prevents your mixture from becoming too watery.  The recipe is also very forgiving.  We luuvvvvvv cheese, so I tend to go a little heavy on the Parmesan and mozzarella, and it really doesn't matter.  This is a wonderful recipe that I will continue making for years to come.  Thank you, Sherlie!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I haven't tried this recipe exactly but it is similar to my mother's. The trick to getting a non-watery patty cooked through is to heat the skillet on med-high until a drop of batter browns quickly (like pancakes), then drop the patties. Once the pattie has formed with a good base, turn down the heat to med-low and let them brown slowly, so the middle has enough time to cook. I use no-stick spray instead of oil and I always spray again before flipping (flip only once, after the bottom is golden brown). My recipe is sans onion, using 1/3 c. Jiffy Mix (or Bisquick) instead of flour, with 1/3 c. parmesan and no motzeralla. I also add a clove of crushed garlic. I'll try it this way soon.

text:
Overall, pretty good, but I think it needs a little tweaking.  I used corn flake crumbs instead of flour.  I also added a lot of garlic and black pepper.  Next time, I'll play around with the corn flake crumbs--I know they need some glue to make them stick together, but I don't think corn flake crumbs or flour or breadcrumbs are the answer.  I'm thinking of mashing a cup of zucchini next time and using that as the glue to hold the shredded zucchini together.  This will give it more of a zucchini taste, which is what I was hoping for in the recipe!

text:
I liked these okay, but my husband was not a fan.  They were a little too greasy for me and he didn't like the fact that they stayed so mushy and runny on the inside after frying.  I thought about cooking them longer, but then the outsides would have been burned.  On the other hand, I didn't want to waste the leftover batter so I poured it into a greased casserole and baked it at 350 for about 40 minutes.  It turned out pretty well, though still not great.  However, I think that it would be an excellent (and cheaper) filling for a quiche.  Just pour it into a pie shell and then bake it until set.

country:
None
text:
You definitely need to drain and blot off the excess water from the zucchini or else the batter is too wet.  I added almond flour and flax seed powder to the batter to soak up the excess liquid, then dredged it in more almond flour and coconut flour and fried it in coconut oil.  To eat, I dipped it in a dip made of yoghurt, lime juice, salt and a little salsa.  Really yummy.  Next time I probably add mushrooms as someone else suggested.

They need some kind of spice to kick up the flavor, maybe chilli pepper, not sure. They were kind of wet so next time I will squeeze the zucchini after I grate it. I will make them again and they will be a vegetable favorite, easy to make and tasty. Thank you for the recipe!

text:
Great idea for zucchini!
As many other reviewers did, we grated the zucchini, stirred in 1/2 t salt, and let it drain in a colander for about 30 minutes. Then we squeezed it out. I added a little cayenne (red) pepper to the mixture, and used chickpea flour instead of regular flour. For a topping, pizza sauce was a great, but a little bit too much; plain yogurt was good. These reminded me of potato pancakes.

text:
I used my food processor to finely chop the zucchini instead of grating, then salted and drained the mixture & squeezed in a paper towel...I was glad I did  when saw how much liquid I was able to squeeze out!
Instead of flour, I used potato flakes and bread crumbs and added garlic powder plus a seasoning mix. I started out pan frying the patties, but finished baking them in my toaster oven for about 15 min on each side at 375 degrees, like others suggested. 

The patties turned out very crispy and delicious!

I love these! I was reading in the reviews here that some people were getting mushy centers. So I altered the recipe to strain some of the water from the zucchini after grating it. this I think helped in the cooking and texture of the patty to be dryer and firmer in the center.

text:
These are absolutely incredible as-is, but I think this recipe will also lend itself well to customization.  Based on a recommendation in the comments, the only thing I did differently was salt the shredded zucchini in a colander and let it drain for 15 minutes while preparing the rest of the ingredients.  Before mixing the zucchini into the other ingredients, I also gave them a final good squeeze to get as much water out as possible.  They browned *very* nicely!

text:
I wanted to feed it to my one year old, so I steamed the zucchini and the onions first and then put them in the food processor. Since they were so soft, instead of ending up with chopped veggies, I got a puree. I resigned myself to zucchini pancakes and they turned out pretty good! I added some creole like seasoning - 1 tsp each of garlic powder, thyme, oregano, paprika and two tsp basil and 1/2 tsp pepper. Fried them on the stove and them seemed to be gooey inside, but I just chalked that up to the cheese. The spices added delicious flavor!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were really good!  I did tweak a bit.  Like other reviews, I grated and squeezed out the excess liquid.  I didn't add salt.  Just my preference.  I substituted panko for the flour, and added garlic, some basil, oregano and red pepper flakes. along with the grated Parmesan and the mozzarella. shaped into patties and baked at 375 on a cast iron skillet.  I turned the patties over after about 15-20 minutes, and browned on the other side.  Squeezing out the excess liquid and not handling the patties much was important.  Served with a side of pear/mozzarella pasta and some balsamic vinegar.  Definitely will add to my no meat day rotation.

text:
I would suggest to really take the time to squeeze all of the water content out of the zucchini by using cheese cloth or a paper towel. They were a little soggy in the middle because I didn't do this step as well as I could have. Also, I bacon wrapped these before I fried them, and OH MY GOODNESS, so good!!! I also used fresh minced garlic. I gave my family the choice of sour cream and chives or marinara sauce. Both were amazing!!! I will be making these again in the near future.

text:
These take a while to make so I suggest you double the recipe and make lots so its worth your time! Hubby and I LOVED them but found there wasn't enough. 

Pro tip: salt the shredded zucchini and let it sit in a bowl for 10-15 minutes. Then rinse and strain it, squeezing out the water. This will remove the additional water from the zucchini, making it easier to pack together.

We are celiac so I had to make the following alterations: I used gluten free (co-op brand all-purpose GF) flour and added pepper. Still the batter was gooey. Nevertheless, the final product was golden brown and delicious. We will make this again and again.

text:
These were really good, though I did make a couple changes. I didn't have any parm on hand, so I used cheddar instead (1/2 cup, still included the 1/2 cup mozz). I also used garlic salt instead of regular salt, mixing it into the mixture before cooking. I then topped with additional diced onion and diced tomato. I'll make again (and a great way to use zucchini for breakfast!). Thanks for the recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just made this recipe and chewing as I'm writing...lol.  It's delicious.   Like everyone, I tweaked the recipe just a tad.  The one thing I did not do was drain the shredded zucchini because that is a chore I despise.  It cooked up just fine.  Still crispy on the outside!  Here were my tweaks: I am on a gluten free diet, so I subbed organic buckwheat flour for regular wheat flour.   I didn't add egg because I wanted to eat these with a poached egg for brunch.   I added a few bits of ham to the batter.   I will definitely make them again!  What I will do differently next time: eliminate the Mozzarella.  I didn't really notice the flavor present in the patty.  Use organic zucchini.  Otherwise, it's loaded with pesticides.  Use less oil.  They were a bit oily.  Try it!  You'll like it!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2901253.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We made this for our dinner tonight. I altered the recipe in the following way(s);
- I used Panko Japanese bread crumbs instead of the flour. I found that in doing so, I eliminated the sometimes pasty after taste or that "glue" effect that flour has in a recipe. It also browns up crispy better than flour.
- I added one additional egg (3 total)
- I eliminated the salt (my wife puts her own on whereas I don't use salt in cooking unless absolutely necessary).
- Finally, since it "read" Italian flavor(s) I used warm/hot spaghetti sauce as a topping. This added any missing spices that are not in the recipe and is an easy sauce for anyone's taste.
What would I do next time? I might try some fresh herbs (chives and cracked pepper) to the mix. Overall, very impressed (and for my wife that is sometimes difficult).
Review:

5

These are great! I've made the recipe twice now - once as directed, another time using the suggestion of another reviewer using mashed potato flakes instead of flour. I thought both were delicious, although the version with the flour I felt needed a little 'something' (serving with tomato sauce or sour cream), whereas the version with the potato flakes were enough on their own since the seasoning from the flakes gave the flavor more depth. I'll probably be using the potato flake version moving forward since that's what my fiance preferred.  Thanks for the recipe!!

text:
I ended up using almost 3 cups of mixed zucchini as well as adding pepper and replacing mozzarella with lite feta cheese. I did that because it's what i had.  I ended up over salting, because I assume, the feta had enough salt. However I made a bunch of little patties and made a side of yogurt shallot sauce with garlic, dill, mint, and lemon. It was awesome. I even whipped it a bit with my hand blender to make it fluffy. All in all, this was simple, easy dish to prep and cook. I will make it again and ease up on the salt in the future.

userID:

Display Name:
Diane King
isPro:

39
favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2111305.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been meaning to make this for a while. Well, I finally did. They are delicious my vegetarian daughter LOVED them. I grated the zucchini on the large hole side of the grater it was easier than I thought it was going to be. I put the zucchini in a strainer salted it a little to draw the water out and  to cut down on bitterness. Let it sit for 10-15 minutes. THE KEY IS TO GET THE WATER OUT OF THE ZUCCHINI. It will be very mushy if you don't. I put mine in paper towels & tried to press out as much water as I could. Instead of flour I used seasoned bread crumbs I followed the recipe for all the other ingredients. I tasted it, seemed bland so I added a little garlic powder  and paprika. I cooked them up and served with a choice of sour cream or marinara sauce.  Yum! We prefer sour cream.

country:
None
text:
These were easy, fast and very tasty. Don't let the photo fool you, they were in no way too greasy or heavy. The out side is crispy but the inside texture is soft and light.  I would reduce the cooking heat to medium instead of medium-high, that way the inside gets cooked  before the outside has a chance to burn. At medium-high heat I ended up with a burnt outside and runny inside. I wouldn't add salt at the end, the 1/2 cup parmesan cheese makes it salty enough.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I cannot eat cheese so I made it a dairy free (except a yogurt topper) with substituting a half a can of white beans mashed before mixing it together. Also added a tsp of garlic paste (it's lazy but so easy) and did half flour/half bread crumbs. I followed the other suggestion to likely salt and dry the zucchini. A little extra salt, pepper and parsley flakes and it came out well. The beans added a creaminess like latkes/potato pancakes (smelled like it too) and a little extra protein for a meatless dish. My husband loved it and said we needed to add it to the rotation for meatless Monday's (or whenever we run low on meat). Two zucchini + the beans made enough for 3 meals. I did add a dollop of Greek yogurt (I can tolerate that better than cheese) and topped with sliced red peppers for color. Happy for leftovers tomorrow!  I could see adding cumin, turmeric and chili powder for a spicier middle eastern flavor. Happy to experiment!

Easy and yummy and my preschooler loved them! Like others, I reduced the flour and added flavored breadcrumbs. I made a double batch (well more like 3.5 cups of zucchini and altered the rest by eyeballing it because it's not a one for one when it comes to eggs) and fried in a cast iron pan and freezing for those weeknight meals.

text:
This has become a favorite side dish for our dinner.  I too use instant potato flakes rather than flour I think it gives a better taste, a teeny pinch of red pepper flakes and a minced small glove of garlic, I say small because I cut the recipe in half for just the two of us. Also I take a grapefruit spoon and just run a line down the center of each zuke to remove the majority of the seeds.  I fry mine in a very well seasoned cast iron pan with just a dab of butter. Healthy and very tasty!

3904193
Display Name:
Preslee76

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing, with some tweaks!! 
Here is what I tweaked:
You have to press the water out of the zucchini after you shred it, I used paper towels. I shredded it with the large holes on a cheese grater. I used two medium sized zucchinis that made about 2 cups shredded. 

I only used a  cup of flour;
I only used a   to  cup of fresh shredded Parmesan. I didnt actually measure;
I only used a  cup of  shredded mozzarella;
I added  to 1 cup of Italian Panko  Private Selection at Kroger;
I added salt and Lawrys seasoned pepper to the mix; 

You pan fry in a cast iron skillet in about 4 TBS of canola.
I dont like vegetable oil. Medium heat to start and then I had to reduce it down to low because the oil was getting too hot. 4-5 minutes on each side;

I pre-formed the patties about 4 at a time,  once I put them in the oil I pressed them with the spatula to flatten them out a little; 
You will have to add a little extra oil after each batch you cook;
I was able to make 12 patties. And per the recipe calculator on MyFitnessPal they average about 84 calories a piece.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were excellent! At first I was going to do as some other reviewers suggested and add to the recipe but decided against it. I'm glad I did, they came out perfect just following the recipe. I can't understand how anyone could say that these were bland or lacking flavor. 
The only thing I did do differently was use  a gluten free all-purpose flour.
Edit after 2nd time making these: 
Now i understand why people were saying these lacked flavor. The first time I made these I used Bob's Red Mill all-purpose gluten free flour. I had an upset stomach and this is the second time I've had problems with Bob's products so I switched to regular flour this time. I found that a lot of the flavor came from the flour the first time. Using regular flour brought out flavors I had missed out on the first time. For round 3 I will add salt and pepper.

text:
I just made these. Mine did indeed turn out too watery but I did not despair and worry: instead, I cooked them as fritters, dropping the "batter" in a warm amount of oil in a frying pan. They were delicious. We used cheddar instead of mozzarella because it's what I had on hand. I think the Parmesan is key, because it's a cheese that provides a flavor. But I think next time I may even try to use crumbled feta, zucchini tasted nice with that in other recipes. Sky's the limit with this, and thanks for sharing :)

text:
I could have sat down and eaten every single morsebut I had to give some to my husband.  I did drain the zucchini with a little salt in a colander,   I added seasoned bread crumbs and extra grated cheese along with some garlic powder.  I cooked the onions in a separate pan until soft and I drained these on paper towels when I took them out of the pan.  But the shredded Provolone cheese gave it such flavor.   I'm making a double recipe tonight and I think I will try baking  them instead of frying.  You can add anything you can think of to this recipe and it will be great.  I found out that the trick is to drain the zucchini and then squeeze as much of the liquid out as you could.     Enjoy!

text:
I make this every 3 months. My family always laments that I don't make enough so next time I will double the recipe. I tweak this recipe a couple ways; I use fresh garlic, tons of red pepper flakes, powdered garlic and dried basil, and I mix cayenne pepper (just a dash) into the sour cream as a dipping sauce. I use panko crumbs instead of flour. I also fry in coconut  oil. I have baked these several times but they don't have the same texture as when I fry them.

text:
I liked the concept of these and will try again making changes. I added about 3/4 cup of Italian seasoned panko breadcrumbs, 3 cloves of garlic, and cayenne pepper and they still were bland. I squeezed the water out of the grated zucchini, mixed everything up, made patties and put them on a paper towel covered plate and put in fridge for about an hour. Sprayed them with olive oil cooking spray and baked on a parchment lined cookie sheet for about 25 minutes. Don't worry if they are soft and falling apart. They will take form when baking or frying. But they were very bland. Next time I will try different cheeses like feta or a smoked Gouda. Probably could do meatballs with these too.
