city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a really good recipe-I made it the first time as is, and it turned out okay.  The second time I made the recipe I tweaked it a little bit, and it turned out even better!  I changed the following things: I doubled the amount of mozzarella cheese.  I also added two cans of white albacore tuna, which really gave it a good flavor and made it more of a "fish"/zucchini patty.  The most important change I made was adding more flour-instead of 1/2 c. I ended adding 1 & 1/4 c., which really helped when frying up the patties-it gave them a better consistency and they browned a lot more nicely than the first time.  I served over rice w/ a little mayo and they were excellent.  My kids also love these on a bun as a delicious sandwhich!

Display Name:

city:

region:

country:

text:
I followed most of the recipe as written, except I started with the grated zucchini (lightly salted) and let it sit for a few minutes and then pressed as much moisture out as possible. I used cheddar instead of mozzarella cheese (it's what I had on hand), and then fried in bacon grease. Salt and pepper was added before I fried the patties and the texture and taste was wonderful. I wish I picked up more zucchini at the farm stand.

text:
Actually pretty good! Used about 2 medium zucchinis and drained as much liquid as I could from them. I then added a fair amount of cheese (used an Italian cheese blend) and added flour until it didn't look too wet (a little more than a cup), also added about a 1/4 cup of diced green pepper along with the onion. Since there was no exact cook time given, I just cooked them until they weren't too soft. Everyone seemed to like them so I would make these again!

country:

text:
Great recipe! My kids loved that Mom was making "zucchini pancakes!" They have good cheesy flavor like a garlic cheese biscuit sort of. I didn't have any problem with the moisture and didn't drain it at all. I did add a bit of garlic powder, some parsley, black pepper, and some Italian seasoning and they were SCRUMPTIOUS!! I enjoyed eating them all by themselves, but I bet they would be great with marinara sauce, too.  We made these a 2nd time with shredded zucchini that I froze in summer when I had too much to use. As the frozen zucchini thawed, there was a lot of liquid, and I did drain that off before adding to the recipe. (I froze 3 cups and ended up with only 2 cups after draining, so it was perfect amount for this recipe!) This time around I forgot the garlic, and while they were still pretty tasty, I missed the garlic.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made and ate these zucchini patties, and my whole family loved them! I doubled the recipe (didn't double the egg) and added fresh basil from the garden and a chopped red bell pepper. Other than that, the only change I made was to omit the salt and sprinkle the patties with a little bit of Tony Chachere's Creole Seasoning as they sizzled in the skillet. I learned through trial and error that it's best not to make the patties too large, because they could turn out a little too soft and floppy. A gentle heaping on a tablespoon should be just right. They are amazing served with some sour cream. I can't wait until my garden tomatoes are ripe so that I can make these again and top them with fresh slices! Thank you, Sherlie, for a delicious new summertime recipe!!

I, too, thought the recipe was quite runny and began to add flour and more cheese.  DH told me to stop and indicated it was probably supposed to be a pancake type batter and to fry it up as is.  I did as instructed and they turned out wonderful and moist, very similar to a potato pancake or hash brown and we both thought they'd be quite nice for breakfast.  I used sharp cheddar instead of mozzarella and did not find them bland at all.  A very nice blend of cheese, onion and squashy goodness. Any other spices would make it something's it's not.

text:
I let grated zucchini set for 30 to 40 minutes once it was grated and put it in a colander, as it will produce lots of moisture (water) that needs to be drained and patted dry

I also formed the mixture into patties and coated with additional bread crumbs and put in a hot skillet. Cooked them for approx. 15-20 minutes These are delicious as is, but you could always top with marinara sauce, sour cream or additional cheese These are very habit forming.. 

This would be good with chopped chives, minced garlic or the tops of green onions in it.. I dont think you can go wrong with anything you try to add to it..

This is the only recipe I use now, and mix a yellow squash with a zucchini.  I shred the veggies on a sheet of parchment paper, spread it out and cover it with a kitchen towel, press on top, to get excess moisture out.  I have used flour but also use Panko.  I add what ever seasonings I want, and have used a Five cheese blend.  You really can't mess this one up.  Just make ahead, refrigerate for a bit, make sure the mixture holds together and brown the patties.  Really good, solid recipe!

text:
Followed some of the other reviewers advice and tweaked the recipe, which is the only reason I gave it 4 instead of 5 stars.  I salted the zucchini and let it sit for a few minutes, then pressed it in a colander to drain some of the water out.  We also grated the onion and some garlic into it.  The garlic gave it a lot of flavor.  I did mostly flour (about 3/4 of the half cup full) and then added some bread crumbs.  The consistency was perfect and they fried up really nicely.  My husband mixed some dried dill into some sour cream to put on top, which worked out well.

text:
I performed the recipe as written exactly.  They were very good, but would benefit from some Italian seasoning or seasoned breadcrumbs like others have suggested.  I made a triple recipe and used six eggs.  I probably should have gone with only 4 or 5.  The consistency was more like a frittata.  I will definitely play with this recipe to get a drier crisper product. They are best on the first day when they are crisp, but still very edible on subsequent days. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Good recipe to use up some garden zucchini. I did allow zucchini to rest in frig for 24 hours after shredding so as to allow juice to settle to bottom of bowl. This made the zucchini not too wet. I added some garlic powder and a touch oregano to add some additional flavor besides the onion. I may try adding a pinch of red pepper flakes next time. To cut down on fat I used cooking spray versus frying in oil. Still came out crispy brown on outside and moist inside.

text:
Hi: 
I didn't read the reviews before making this recipe and as a result my 'patties' were falling apart as they were  too soggy/wet from the zucchini. Definitely recommend getting all the moisture out first. 
I compensated for moisture by adding some flax meal and cornstarch. Also, added some fresh crab chopped from my food processor, some Tabasco sauce, more onion and lots of garlic as others mentioned, as well as used parsley and green onions from my garden, then some very flavorful Dubliner Irish cheese along with the Parmesan and about a Tablespoon of chili powder. For the leftovers tomorrow I'm also adding some of my home dehydrated bell peppers! Although they are still falling apart from being too moist they taste TERRIFIC!

text:
9 years later and still a great basic recipie! I did it according to directions, except I made 6 inch patties which yielded 6 patties total, did not salt (cheese has enough) and added pepper. I have a gas stove and used a very large skillet. My setting started st 7 and half way through the patties I turned it down to 6. I put the new patties on the cool side of the pan and waited until both sides were firmed up, then transferred to the hot side to brown. I am a vegetarian and have been since birth and it's rare that I get to eat patties that taste so good and don't cost so much. Home made is where it is at, and the recipe was way easy.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-07-15T18:43:44.09
helpfulCount:
0

text:
Really yummy and easy to make. I followed the suggestion of the poster who said to substitute instant potato flakes for the flour, and I'm glad I did. The potato gave the patties a nice crunch to them. My only caution for those making this recipe is to keep an eye on the patties, they cook super fast and can go from done to burned in a matter of seconds.

text:
I was pleasantly surprised with this recipe. It turned out really well. My husband loved it (5 stars) and I thought it was really good (4 stars). I did change some things based on the other reviews. I squeezed the liquid out of the zucchini after I grated it. I didn't have any onion so I added some onion powder, garlic powder, and Italian seasoning. I used whole wheat flour and only about 3/4 c of cheese total. I used only about a drop of olive oil for every three patties and supplemented with non stick spray. I'll definitely make these again.

Very good recipe. Will definitely make again. Tweaked the recipe a tad: as others suggested I squeezed the shredded zucchini to get as much water as I could out of them (for like 3 minutes total [don't stress about it]); I also cooked the onion (and garlic, and red pepper [and imaginably anything else you want]) a little in some olive oil before putting in with the zucchini/egg/flour/etc. Other than that, I followed the recipe and got 6 nice sized patties out of it all. I also put salsa on top of the patties I ate, which gave them a nice flavor, although they tasted very good and cheesy alone.   Good recipe. Bravo!

My husband is a very picky eater and turned his nose up at the steamed zucchini I made the other night, but he enjoyed these :) Will make again & again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe last night, and it is delish! Definitely a keeper. I didn't even add any toppings, it was that good. I followed a lot of the suggestions such as substituting some flour with breadcrumbs, adding green onions, garlic and other seasonings etc. I actually only had about 1/4 cup of cheddar cheese, so I used that plus some Asiago cheese. Came out pretty well. I also peeled the zucchini as wasn't sure whether the skin would be too tough. Next time I'll try with unpeeled zucchini. I'm African, so definitely had to spice it up with some Cayenne pepper, and different seasonings...a pinch of this and that. We don't measure, just eyeball and go off of taste, so couldn't really tell you what worked. Oh, and I also forgot to beat the eggs before adding, but it still turned out okay. They were soft and I had to be careful so they didn't fall apart...maybe I needed to squeeze the grated zucchini dry just a little bit more. I will definitely be making again, and adding as a regular item on the menu. And hey, the best part is, since I went off of taste and 'eyeballin' for the seasonings, it could come out slightly different each time, thus keeping it fresh and 'new'...LOL.

I made these to take to a cookout and everyone loved them ! I served them with blue cheese dressing to dip into. After reading the other reviews I also added a few little twists of my own which is the best part of this recipe. It is so adaptable. I added another egg and changed the flour to 1/4 C and added 1/2 C Italian bread crumbs. I also added some chopped red pepper,   minced garlic and fresh parsley. They were outstanding. I'm making another batch to freeze for later, this time I'm adding "crab"(2 cans drained), not enough to call it a crab cake but enough to make it awesome.

None
text:
Very good!  I used a mix of zucchini, carrots, and summer squash for the vegetables and drained them between two plates with a weight on top between paper towels after grating.  Threw in some chives and 2 cloves garlic with the onion.  I used half cheddar and half mozzarella for the cheese mix with a few tsps of parmesan.  I subbed some Panko bread crumbs for 1/3 of the flour.  I filled a 1/3-cup measure for each patty and tapped out onto the frying pan, and the patties held together very well.  Served with plain, Greek yogurt.  Delicious, nutritious, easy!

text:
This is a great base recipe - the proportions are good, but I think that they would be a little bland w/o the modifications suggested by earlier reviewers.  I used Itailan breadcrumbs in mine.  Though, it turned out that I wasn't too keen on how they dominated the flavor so I will probably do half Italian and half plain breadcrumbs next time.  I also added some shredded carrots for color/flavor and because I had them on hand.  Red pepper flakes and some extra garlic were a must for me.  I will definitely do these again with some more tweaking to get them just right.

text:
This is now our accompaniment to meatballs instead of pasta!  I used several modifications to fit our needs: 1)  Used almost 2x amount of zucchini, salted for 15 min. and then squeezed dry 2)  add 2 cloves minced garlic and some minced parseley, and pepper 3)  used shredded gouda (because I had that on hand)  They are a bit "goopy" to handle at first, but I formed the patties and put them in the freezer for 10-15 min to firm them up.  Turned out fabulous with no leftovers.  Delicious with marinara.

Really tasty.  I made these with rice flour so my child who is allergic to gluten could eat these.  I'm glad I did!  These are her new favorite food - she ate 7 patties for lunch one day, then 3 more while she was waiting for dinner.  We eat them with marinara sauce. I followed the recipe the first time, but was out of parmesan the next time I made them, so I subbed feta, and they were still delicious.  Thanks!!

text:
I have had this recipe for a while and would like to add a little bit to this. If you shake out some (how much is up to you) crushed dried red pepper into this recipe before you fry it up, you will see the taste improves and has a little bite or spice to it.  Otherwise it is an excellent recipe, everyone loves it, and a great way to use up a large amount of zucchini in a short time :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are wonderful! The only thing I did different was to add jack cheese instead of mozz. because that is what I had. I husband and son who won't touch zucchini loved these. In fact I knew they wouldn't even try these had they known that they were zucchini so I told them they were potato pancakes. When they finished them off and commented on how delicious they were, I told them that they were made with zucchini. They liked them so much that they both took them cold to work the next day for lunch. Great way to use up some of the abundant zucchini! Edit: I've been making these for years and just this last time I squeezed out all the water from the zucchini before mixing everything together. What a difference! I will never skip that step again. Also, I used a couple Tbsp. of brown rice flour instead of the white flour and it worked great. Couldn't tell the difference. Now they are gluten-free!

I shredded my zucchini in the food processor, then following Annabelle's brilliant suggestion, spun it dry using my salad spinner and gave it a final pat dry.  The instant mashed potatoes sounded interesting, but I was nervous about the substitution, so I used 1/4 cup flour and 1/4 cup instant mashed potatoes.  Otherwise followed the recipe exactly and cooked them on my electric griddle.  They were wonderful! (I even ate one cold the next day, and it was good, too.)

text:
These patties were very good! I think I will play around with the seasoning in these, maybe add some cilantro. Thank You Sherlie!  Update:10-25-09. I made these again last night and the first batch did not turn out well. I had added too much zucchini and they went all over the pan plus I added Way too much oil. Silly mistakes. I regrouped, drained some oil in a bowl,for future use. I added more flour to the batter and that was the ticket! They stayed together, browned up beautifully and tasted Fabulous!! I used a Mexican cheese called Cotija. It is a dry cheese, in place of the Parmesan, really good and tasty. I served them with a pico de gallo,(fresh salsa) and Mexican crema(sour cream).

text:
Simple and easy comfort food that's almost good for you! When I make these, I grate the zucchini by hand and then squeeze as much water out as I can through a dish towel / cheese cloth. (My mom forgot to do this once, and the patties were too mushy.) I also use about half the recommended amount of Parmesan (a little goes a long way) and add a dash of garlic powder.

Yum Yum Yum! These were so delicious and so simple to make. I grated the zuchini, onions, some garlic (not in the recipe but thought I would add it) and the cheese all in the food processor. I did find that the mixture was a bit wet. Not so much that I wouldn't have been able to shape them into patties, but I added a few tablespoons of bread crumbs anyway. They were really tasty all on their own. I will be making this recipe again and again.

I loved it.  My husband suggested next time to chop the onions up finely, he didn't care for the larger chopped size.  I had one right after they were made and had to leave, so when I came home later that evening, I threw the leftovers into my toaster oven on the pan and set it to medium. It was AWESOME reheated this way, makes a crisp crunch, not a soggy greasy mess like the microwave would have.  Will make again and again!

text:
Very good, and versatile. I made mine a bit more Southwestern in style, only because those were the ingredients I had on hand. I used cheddar cheese instead of mozzarella and added a cup of frozen corn (defrosted) since I didn't have quite enough zucchini and tossed in a couple cloves of minced garlic. Served them with salsa -- they were a nice hearty side dish with grilled turkey tenderloin. They weren't bad warmed up the next day, either.  I have also made these with just corn, scraping the kernels off of a couple leftover ears. They reminded me of Grandma's corn fritters.

text:
My entire family,including 2 vegetarians and grandson, loved this recipe. I doubled it.  For the meat eaters I fixed fish to go along with it and used salsa as a topper if they wanted it. I also used potato flakes instead of flour, my daughter is allergic to flour, and added extra potato flakes to absorb the liquid from the squash, so no need to drain the squash. my daughter ate the 2 left over patties on gluten free toasted bread with mustard the next day and loved it.

We thought these were great.  I used purple onion, because that was all I had, but I think next time I might scale back a bit on the onion.  The first one I cooked, as the guinea pig, was a bit too mushy in the middle, although it was golden brown on the outside.  So I turned the heat down just a bit and let the rest of them cook a little bit longer than is stated in the recipe.  My husband even liked these, and he's not a bit zucchini fan.  Thanks for the great recipe, we'll be making these again.
